awd_titl_txt: Implementation Project: Improving Minority Participation and Completion through STEM at Dillard University- IMPACTS at DU
awd_abstract_narration:
Implementation Projects in the Historically Black Colleges and Universities - Undergraduate program provide support to design, implement, study and assess comprehensive institutional efforts to increase the numbers of students and the quality of their preparation by strengthening science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) education and research. This implementation project at Dillard University provides a multilayered approach to broaden opportunities for African-American students to succeed in STEM majors. The focus of the project is on retaining and graduating students in STEM fields and preparing them for graduate school or the workforce. The project is guided and informed by an on-going evaluation, as well as by internal and external advisory committees.

The project has the goals to: increase the number of students applying to Dillard with STEM as their intended majors, and increase the number of students retained year-to-year through deliberate on-ramping and monitoring of students' course progression; improve preparation of STEM majors through curriculum redesign and technology-infused coursework; and strengthen Dillard's research and workforce development efforts  and further develop research experiences for undergraduate STEM students. To achieve these goals, the project will utilize innovative strategies to recruit high school students with STEM interests; provide a bridge program to on-ramp incoming freshman students with STEM major aspirations; redesign gateway courses and enhance existing student supports to retain STEM majors; and provide research and workforce development opportunities for both STEM faculty and students. These holistic approaches will demonstrate a reliable performance model for small colleges and universities that are concerned about recruiting, retaining, and preparing undergraduate STEM majors for the next step.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The Implementation Project: Improving Minority Participation and Completion through STEM at Dillard University- IMPACTS at DU, funded through the NSF Historically Black Colleges and Universities Undergraduate Program (HBCU UP), aimed to enhance the pipeline and ecosystem for STEM students at Dillard University (DU). The project sought to improve recruitment and retention of underrepresented minorities in STEM, implement curriculum redesigns, and provide robust student support mechanisms. The overarching goals included increasing STEM enrollment and retention, improving student preparation through technology-infused coursework, and strengthening research and workforce development infrastructure.

A significant intellectual contribution of IMPACTS@DU II was the development and implementation of redesigned STEM courses, particularly in Biology (BIO 111/L), Chemistry (CHE 111/L), and Mathematics (MAT 121, MAT 121A). These redesigns, incorporating technology such as ALEKS and Launchpad, enhanced student engagement and improved outcomes. Data indicate that IMPACTS@DU II scholars performed better academically compared to their non-participating peers, with higher GPAs and lower withdrawal or failure rates in redesigned courses. Additionally, faculty participation in the Faculty Research Community of Practice (FRCOP) facilitated pedagogical advancements, promoting interactive and technology-integrated teaching approaches. Faculty members involved in the project also contributed to the broader STEM education community through research publications and conference presentations, disseminating findings on effective teaching strategies and student support models. Several faculty members published peer-reviewed research articles with students, further demonstrating the scholarly impact of the project.

Beyond curricular changes, the project fostered an environment conducive to undergraduate research and faculty-student collaborations. Faculty received competitive seed grants to support research initiatives, resulting in publications in reputable scientific journals. Faculty members contributed to interdisciplinary research on environmental science and engineering applications. The research findings from IMPACTS@DU II were presented at national conferences such as the Emerging Researchers National (ERN) Conference in STEM and the Annual Biomedical Research Conference for Minoritized Scientists (ABRCMS), allowing students and faculty to engage with broader academic and industry communities.

The broader impacts of IMPACTS@DU II were substantial, particularly in increasing diversity within STEM disciplines. The project actively addressed the underrepresentation of minority students in STEM by implementing initiatives such as the Pre-Freshman Summer Bridge Program, which provided academic preparation and mentorship. Additionally, gender disparity trends were observed, with more female students enrolling in biology and chemistry, while male students dominated computer science enrollment. The program also strengthened industry partnerships, creating internship opportunities and career pathways for students. These efforts contributed to developing a more inclusive and well-prepared technical workforce, ensuring that underrepresented students had the skills and experiences necessary to succeed in STEM careers.

IMPACTS@DU II scholars exhibited improved retention rates and academic performance. A GPA analysis showed that program scholars had an average GPA 0.45 points higher than non-participating STEM students. The infusion of ALEKS in chemistry and mathematics courses resulted in a reduction of withdrawal and failure rates. Additionally, faculty training in technology-enhanced teaching expanded the reach and efficacy of these innovations. Through seed grants, internships, and faculty-led research collaborations, students engaged in hands-on learning experiences. Career fairs and industry partnerships further exposed students to STEM career pathways. Early alert systems, peer mentoring, and proactive advising were implemented, improving student academic support structures. However, the program identified gaps in faculty advising loads and proposed decentralized student support access across campus. Many program components, such as the summer bridge program and redesigned courses, have been institutionalized at DU, ensuring long-term benefits beyond the funding period.

IMPACTS@DU II made significant strides in advancing STEM education at Dillard University. By increasing minority participation, enhancing teaching and learning through curriculum redesigns, and fostering workforce preparedness, the project contributed meaningfully to the broader mission of diversifying STEM fields. The sustained adoption of key initiatives ensures that DU will continue to build upon these successes, equipping students with the skills and experiences necessary for academic and professional excellence in STEM.

 

 


Last Modified: 03/04/2025
Modified by: Eric L Buckles
